column1: Herzogenaurach (German: [hɛʁtsoːɡn̩ˈʔaʊʁax] (listen); East Franconian: Herziaura) is a town in the district of Erlangen-Höchstadt
column3: Germany. It is best known for being the home of the major international sporting goods companies Adidas and Puma
column4: as well as the large car parts manufacturer Schaeffler Group.

column1: Herzogenaurach is situated in the Middle Franconia area of Bavaria
column2: approx. 23 km (or 14 miles) northwest of Nuremberg. The town is located on the Aurach river
column3: a tributary of the Regnitz river.

column1: Herzogenaurach was first mentioned in a document from 1002 under the name of Uraha when Holy Roman Emperor Henry II granted the town to the Prince-Bishopric of Bamberg.
Herzogenaurach has gained global fame as the birthplace of two giant sporting goods companies: Adidas and Puma
column2: each founded respectively by brothers Adolf Dassler and Rudolf Dassler
column3: after an acrimonious familial split in 1948. Both companies' headquarters are still located in the town
column4: originally on opposite sides of the Aurach River
column5: and brand loyalty was sharply divided as well. For many years
column6: Adidas and Puma workers would not associate with each other
column7: and even when Adolf and Rudi died
column8: they were buried in opposite ends of the town's cemetery. These differences have cleared up over the years.

column1: Also the headquarters of Schaeffler Group are located in Herzogenaurach.
Even the town's two football clubs were divided by the Adidas/Puma split: ASV Herzogenaurach was supported by Adidas
column2: while FC Herzogenaurach endorsed Puma's footwear. Both clubs still play at amateur level.

column1: Herzogenaurach was the location of a military airfield beginning in the 1930s. The airfield was originally designed as an airfield by a French architect and constructed by the Deutsche Luftwaffe (Air Force)
column2: named Deutsche Fliegerschule (German pilot school). Initially
column3: the post was limited in its use as a Hitler youth training school due to limitations imposed by the Versailles Treaty after World War I.

column2: fighter pilots soon began training in civilian clothing. In March 1936
column3: the Luftwaffe took official control. The airfield was mainly used as a fuelling point for aircraft providing air cover for troops during the invasion of Austria and Czechoslovakia. On 9 November of each year
column4: planes took off from the airfield to fly over the party rallies staged at Zeppelinwiese (Zeppelin Field) in Nuremberg.

column1: During the Western Allied invasion of Germany in April 1945
column2: the United States Third Army seized the airfield. It was designated as ALG R-29. It was first occupied by a transportation unit followed by the USAAF 354th Fighter Group in May. In May 1946
column3: the 2nd Radio Corps took over the installation and renamed it "Herzo Base". In 1947 the base was occupied by the U.S. Army Security Agency up until 1971
column4: when it was replaced by the 210th Field Artillery Group (re-designated as the 210th Field Artillery Brigade on 16 September 1980) which occupied Herzo Base until 1992. Then Herzo Base was included in the base closure plan. On 4 August 1992
column5: the installation was officially returned to the German Government. It has since served as a civilian recreational airfield
